We developed two types of silver promoted Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts by sol-gel coupled with two different impregnation methods, which exhibited distinct catalytic activity and tunable selectivity in the dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation. Impregnation method A was introduction of Ag promoter after calcination of Cu/SiO2 while impregnation method B was before its calcination. As a result, the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts possessed inferior catalytic activity but higher methyl glycolate (MG) selectivity, while the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited superior low-temperature catalytic activity and higher ethylene glycol (EG) selectivity under the same conditions (P = 2.0 MPa, T = 463 K, H2/DMO molar ratio = 50). Experimental results revealed that doping with silver species into Cu/SiO2 catalysts by using impregnation method A would aggravate the agglomeration of Cu particles and decrease Cu dispersion, thereby reducing the catalytic activity. In contrast, the introduction of silver promoter by using impregnation method B was conducive to inhibiting the growth of Cu particles, promoting Cu dispersion, and enhancing the interaction between Cu and Ag species. Moreover, the distribution of Cu species was regulated and thus maintain suitable Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) ratio after Ag addition, thereby improving the catalytic activity over the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst. In addition, the monometallic Cu/SiO2 catalyst deactivated rapidly within 100 h, while the average EG selectivity of the optimal Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst was no less than 97% even after 150 h stability test at a low temperature of 463 K. Systematic study found that the Ag promoter in Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst played an essential role in stabilizing the catalyst structure and reducing the sintering and agglomeration of copper particles, thus greatly improving the stability of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Graphical abstract The Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts possessed inferior catalytic activity but higher MG selectivity, while the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited superior low-temperature catalytic activity and higher EG selectivity in DMO hydrogenation process Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Dimethyl oxalate hydrogenation Ethylene glycol Cu/SiO2 catalyst Silver Deactivation 1 Introduction As outstanding organic solvents and crucial chemical intermediates, MG and EG are extensively employed in many fields due to their unique molecular structure [1–4]. MG can be widely applied in the manufacture of glycolic acid, DL-glycine and malonate ester [1,2]. And EG can be widely used as an antifreezing agent, lubricant, plasticizer, surfactant and so on [3,4]. With the shrinking of the crude oil resources, synthesis of EG from syngas gains increasing attention. The technical route includes three major steps: oxidative coupling of methyl nitrite (CH3NO2) and CO to dimethyl oxalate (DMO), hydrogenation of DMO to intermediate MG, and then further hydrogenation of MG to target product EG (Scheme 1 ) [5–8]. First and foremost is to prepare an efficient, stable and environmentally friendly hydrogenation catalyst of this process. According to the literature, the Cu/SiO2 catalysts are considered the most promising and most widely investigated in DMO hydrogenation reactions due to their high activity for selective hydrogenation of C=O bond compared with other types of catalysts [9–12]. However, for large-scale industrial production, the catalytic activity and stability of the monometallic Cu/SiO2 catalysts still need to be further improved. Generally, there are two approaches to solve these problems. The first approach is modifying the preparation methods (e.g., ion-exchange, impregnation, deposition-precipitation, ammonia evaporation hydrothermal, and sol-gel method, etc.) [13,14]. These preparation methods have been widely used to prepare the Cu/SiO2 catalysts with high metallic copper dispersion and modest interaction between active component copper and support SiO2. Another approach is doping promoter additives to form the stable bimetallic structure such as Cu-Ni, Cu-Zn, Cu-In, Cu-La, Cu-Ce, Cu-B, Cu-Au and Cu-Ag [15–21]. These promoter additives are supposed to suppress the growth of Cu particles, improve the Cu dispersion, enhance the metal–support interaction and maintain appropriate Cu0 and Cu+ distribution, thereby improving the hydrogenation performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Notably, Cu, Ag and Au are often doped with each other to form intermetallic compounds or alloys due to their similar structure and physicochemical properties. Yin et al. reported that CuAu alloy nanoparticles developed by ammonia-evaporation–deposition–precipitation method were highly active and selective for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG [22]. The optimal Cu3Au2/HMS catalyst obtained the highest yield of MG (90%) under the optimized conditions (T = 453 K, P = 3 MPa, H/E = 120 mol/mol, LHSV = 0.2 h−1). Huang et al. found that doping with an appropriate amount of Ag into Cu/SiO2 catalyst was conducive to enhancing the catalytic activity and stability during the hydrogenation of DMO to EG [18]. The optimal Cu1-Ag0.05/SiO2 catalyst could maintain about 97% EG selectivity and 100% DMO conversion after 150 h at 463 K and 3.0 MPa. Characterization results revealed that the formation of Cu-Ag alloy structure on the surface of the catalyst could maintain appropriate Cu0 / Cu+ proportion and suppress the agglomeration of Cu nanoparticles. In addition, Ren et al. deemed that the intense mutual effect between Cu and Ag species could improve Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts catalytic performance by increasing the dispersion of metal and obtaining the appropriate Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) ratio [21]. These charming findings provide enlightening inspiration for the design and preparation of DMO hydrogenation catalysts. In our previous work, we successfully introduced the cyclodextrin and boron promoters to modify the Cu/SiO2 catalysts by the sol-gel method, achieving delightful results [23,24]. Therefore, for further enhancement of the catalytic performance of Cu/SiO2 catalysts, we have developed two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts by sol-gel coupled with two different impregnation methods by changing the order of adding the Ag promoter, named Cu-Ag/SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag/SiO2 (B) catalysts, respectively. The catalytic hydrogenation performance of the two types of Cu/SiO2 catalysts modified by Ag promoter was evaluated and compared detailedly. Furthermore, the physicochemical properties of these two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts were characterized to find out the underlying causes of the difference in the catalytic performance. Moreover, the reasons for the rapid deactivation of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst in the DMO hydrogenation stability experiment and the role of the Ag promoter in maintaining the catalytic performance of the catalyst are also discussed in depth. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Cu-Ag/SiO2 (A) catalysts preparation Method A: The Cu-Ag/SiO2 (A) catalysts with 15 wt% Cu loading were developed by using sol-gel coupled with impregnation method. The specific preparation method procedure was described as follows: (1) 13 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved in 45 g distilled water in a beaker under stirring to obtain a blue transparent solution. 100 g of ethanol and 70 g of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) were added and stirred vigorously in a water bath at 343 K for 1-2 h to form a sol-gel. (2) The sol-gel was then aged at room temperature for 24 h and dried by temperature ramping program (343 K for 17 h, 363 K for 40 h, and then 493 K for 4 h) to form Cu/SiO2 catalyst precursors. (3) The Cu/SiO2 catalyst precursors were calcined at 573 K for 5 h, crushed, sieved to 20-40 meshes, and then denoted as Cu/SiO2 catalyst. (5) A certain amount of AgNO3 with the Ag/Cu mass ratio of 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, was dissolved in 30 mL of distilled water. (6) 20 g Cu/SiO2 catalysts with a particle size of 20-40 meshes were added to the above AgNO3 solution, immersed at room temperature for 3-5 h. (7) Finally, the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts (x representing Ag/Cu mass ratio) were obtained after drying at 393 K for 12 h and calcining at 573 K for 5 h. 2.1.2 Cu-Ag/SiO2 (B) catalysts preparation Method B: (1) The dried Cu/SiO2 catalyst precursors were developed according to the preparation method in 2.2.1, and then crushed, sieved to 20-40 meshes. (2) A certain amount of AgNO3 with the Ag/Cu mass ratio of 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, was dissolved in 30 mL of distilled water. (3) 20 g dried Cu/SiO2 catalyst precursors with a particle size of 20-40 meshes were added to the above AgNO3 solution, immersed at room temperature for 3-5 h. (4) Finally, the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts (x representing Ag/Cu mass ratio) were obtained after drying at 393 K for 12 h and calcining at 573 K for 5 h. 2.1.3 Cu/SiO2 and Ag/SiO2 catalysts preparation A Cu/SiO2 catalyst with 15 wt% Cu and an Ag/SiO2 catalyst with 3 wt% Ag were similarly developed by using sol-gel method. The specific preparation procedures were as reported before [24]. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations In this paper, various characterization (such as N2 adsorption and desorption, N2O titration, XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, STEM-EDX mapping, XPS, XAES, etc.) methods were utilized extensively. The purpose was to further explore and distinguish the effect of silver promoter on the structures, surface chemistry and structure-activity relationship of two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts. More detailed operation processes were summarized in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic tests The hydrogenation performance evaluation experiments of the Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts were carried out on a 1200 mm length stainless steel single-tube reactor (10 mm internal diameter). Specifically, 10 mL of catalyst sample (20-40 meshes) was centered in the constant temperature zone of reactor, and the rest of the space is filled with magnetic ring packing. Subsequently, the catalyst sample was reduced and activated by high purity hydrogen for 8 h at 623 K and 1.0 MPa pressure. After being reduced and activated, the reactants (20 wt% DMO methanol solution) and hydrogen were mixed and gasified in the preheater and then transported to the reactor. The actual reaction conditions were as follows: the DMO weight liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 0.2 h−1, H2/DMO molar ratio of 50:1, and reaction pressure of 2.0 MPa. The reactants and products are separated and analyzed on a gas chromatograph (GC-900C). The calculation formulas for the conversion rate of DMO and the selectivity to various products (MG and EG) are as follows: Conversion ( DMO ) = n DMO , in − n DMO , out n DMO , in × 100 % Selectivity ( MG ) = n MG , out n DMO , in − n DMO , out × 100 % Selectivity ( EG ) = n EG , out n DMO , in − n DMO , out × 100 % In the catalyst recycling and reutilization test, the used catalyst were regenerated by high purity hydrogen for 8 h at 623 K and 1.0 MPa pressure. Under the previous reaction conditions, the regenerated catalysts were re-evaluated for catalytic performance test. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity and stability As presented in Scheme 2 , the biggest difference between the preparation methods of two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts lied in the order of adding the Ag promoter during the preparation process. The Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts were developed by impregnating Cu/SiO2 catalysts with different concentrations of AgNO3 solution. While the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts were developed by impregnating Cu/SiO2 catalyst precursors with different concentrations of AgNO3 solution. To explore and compare the different effects of the additive Ag on the two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts, the DMO hydrogenation performance test of the catalysts was evaluated unde the same conditions. As shown in Fig . 1a, with the increase of the Ag/Cu mass ratio, the DMO conversion (Con.DMO) of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts did not change greatly, ranging from 97.1% to 99.9%. However, after the addition of Ag promoter, the selectivity of EG (Sel.EG) decreased significantly from 87.7% to 4.7%, while that of MG increased from 10.7% to 95.1%. Among the catalysts, Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst exhibited the best catalytic activity (Con.DMO = 99.9%, Sel.EG = 64.1%). However, the Sel.EG of unmodified Cu/SiO2 catalyst was 87.1% (Con.DMO = 97.2%) at 473 K (Fig. S1). Obviously, the selectivity of MG (Sel.MG) was remarkably correlated linearly with the Ag/Cu mass ratio (Ag/Cu>0.04), and Cu-Ag0.2/SiO2 (A) catalyst afforded the highest Sel.MG of 95.1% at 473 K. In view of the Cu-Ag0.2/SiO2 (A) catalyst with such high Sel.MG, it could be used as an effective candidate to produce MG. In addition, we also investigated the relationship between catalytic performance of Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst and reaction temperature in range of 443 K–493 K (Fig. 2a). With the increase of temperature, the Con.DMO and Sel.EG of the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst sharply increased, reaching the maximum of 100% and 93.6% at 493 K. However, under identical reaction conditions, the Sel.EG of unmodified Cu/SiO2 catalyst was only 89.7% (Con.DMO = 100%), as shown in Fig. S1. These results showed that although introducing Ag species into Cu/SiO2 catalyst by using preparation method A could lead to a decrease in the catalytic activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, it could also inhibit the formation of by-products to obtain higher Sel.EG at high reaction temperatures. As exhibited in Fig. 1 b, the catalytic performance of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts showed a volcanic trend with the increase of the Ag/Cu mass ratio. Among them, the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst exhibited the optimal catalytic activity, and lower or higher Ag/Cu mass ratio would lead to a decrease in the catalytic performance. The Con.DMO and Sel.EG of Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst were 100% and 97.4% at 463 K, while that of pure Cu/SiO2 catalyst were only 94.7% and 51.1% under the same reaction conditions (Fig. S1). Besides, the Ag/SiO2 catalyst exhibited extremely poor catalytic activity, with only 6.7% and 2.4% for Con.DMO and Sel.EG at 463K (Table S1). These results indicated that the introduction of Ag species to Cu/SiO2 catalyst could remarkably enhance the DMO hydrogenation activity and increase the Sel.EG of Cu/SiO2 catalyst. In addition, the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst was further evaluated as a function of temperature in the range of 433–483 K, and the related results were shown in Fig. 2 b. It was apparent that both Con.DMO and Sel.EG increased when the temperature increased to 463 K, and then the Sel.EG declined on further increasing the temperature. The result could be attributed to the over-hydrogenation and dehydration of EG to by-products, including ethanol (EtOH), 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) and 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO). Furthermore, it was essential to compare the conversion frequency (TOF) values, which presented the intrinsic catalytic activity of the catalysts. Obviously, the TOF values of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts were significantly lower than that of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts, which was consistent with the above activity evaluation results. For Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts, the TOF values exhibited a trend of increasing at first and then decreasing (Table 1 ). When the Ag/Cu mass ratio was 0.04, the TOF values reached the apex of 3.0 h−1, while that of Cu/SiO2 catalyst was only 2.5 h−1. These results suggested that doping with appropriate Ag promoter by using the preparation method B generated more active sites on the Cu/SiO2 catalyst surface and improved the catalytic activity. As shown in Table 2 , the DMO conversion and MG selectivity of these reported catalysts in the DMO-to-MG reaction were in range of 83.2%–100.0% and 92.0%–99.8%, respectively. And the DMO conversion and EG selectivity of these reported catalysts in the DMO-to-MG reaction were in range of 99.5%–100.0% and 91.0%–97.0%, respectively (Table 2). Compared with these reported catalysts, Cu-Ag0.2/SiO2 (A) catalyst and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst exhibited better MG yield (Con.DMO = 97.1%, Sel.MG = 95.1%) and EG yield (Con.DMO = 100%, Sel.EG = 97.4%) than most of the catalysts, respectively. Besides, Cu-Ag0.2/SiO2 (A) catalyst and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst also had the advantages of simple preparation method and mild reaction conditions, so they had greater industrial application prospects. Up to now, the short lifetime of Cu-based catalysts is still a major issue that limits the large-scale industrial application of Cu/SiO2 catalysts in DMO hydrogenation reaction. Fig. 3 displayed the comparison of catalytic stability between pure Cu/SiO2 and optimized Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst. The unmodified Cu/SiO2 catalyst exhibited poor catalytic stability, and the Con.DMO and Sel.EG dramatically decreased within 100h from 94% and 62% to about 47% and 30% at 463 K, respectively. Nevertheless, the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst maintained stable Con.DMO (100%) and Sel.EG (97%) within 150 h. These results indicated that an appropriate Ag/Cu mass ratio by using preparation method B could significantly enhance the catalytic stability of Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Besides, the Cu-Ag0.2/SiO2 (A) catalyst also presented excellent MG selectivity and remarkable catalytic stability, maintaining Con.DMO (97%) and Sel.EG (95%) at 473 K without significant reduction within 150 h (Fig. S2). These results suggested that doping with silver promoter by using preparation method A could improve the MG selctivity and enhance the stability of Cu/SiO2 catalysts during the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. The recycling experiments of the used Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst after 150 h of reaction were carried out for three times and the related results were presented in Fig. S3. In each recycling experiment, the Con.DMO and Sel.EG of the used Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst remained around 100% and 97% after 20 h of reaction, respectively. For comparison, the same recycling experiment were carried out on the deactivated Cu/SiO2 catalyst after 100 h of reaction. As shown in Fig. S4, after 4 h reaction of the first recycling experiment, the Con.DMO and Sel.EG of the used Cu/SiO2 catalyst were greatly improved from 47% and 30% to 83% and 56%, respectively. However, the Con.DMO and Sel.EG of the used Cu/SiO2 catalyst dropped sharply after 20 h of reaction. The same pattern could be found in the second and third recycling experiments, and the activity and stability of the regenerated Cu/SiO2 catalyst were worse than that of the first time. These results indicate that reduction regeneration could only temporarily improve the activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, but the catalyst deactivated rapidly, and the deactivation rate became faster with the increase of regeneration times. It also showed from another point of view that doping with Ag promoter by using preparation method B could enhance the stability of Cu/SiO2 catalysts. 3.2 Structural and textural properties Tables 3 and 4 presented the actual loadings of Cu and Ag species for the two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts, which were measured by ICP-OES. Notably, all the theoretical loadings of copper and silver species were slightly higher than the actual values, but the actual Ag/Cu mass ratios were basically consistent with the theoretical values . As shown in Fig. S5, all the catalysts displayed typical IV type N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms with H2-type hysteresis loops, which indicated that all the catalysts possess mesoporous structure [28]. After introducing Ag species to Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the shapes of the hysteresis loop of the N2 adsorption–desorption were slight change, which suggested that the addition of Ag species had no significant effect on the pore structure. Table 3 also summarized the BET surface area (SBET), pore volume (Vp) and pore diameter (Dp) of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts. Prior to the modification, the SBET, Vp and Dp of the unmodified Cu/SiO2 catalyst were higher than those of the Ag/SiO2 catalyst. However, the SBET of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts showed different degrees of decrease after adding Ag promoter. Compared with other Ag doped Cu/SiO2 catalysts, the SBET value of Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst reached a relatively high point (368.7 m2·g−1). More or less Ag promoter would result in a greater reduction of SBET. Moreover, it was apparent that the Vp and Dp of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst did not change significantly with the gradual increase of Ag promoter content. In addition, the Cu dispersion (DCu) and Cu surface area (SCu) were also listed in Table 3. According to literature reports, the oxidation reaction of metallic silver species generally occured at temperatures higher than 658 K or lower than 373 K for more than 5 h during the process of N2O titration [29]. The DCu and SCu showed the similar trend as the SBET, which decreased from 17.9 and 19.2 m2·g−1 to 15.1 and 15.8 m2·g−1, respectively. Among them, the DCu and SCu of the optimal Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst were only 17.2 and 19.0 m2·g−1. These results suggested that doping with Ag promoter by using preparation method A would lead to the decrease of the SBET, DCu and SCu, thereby reducing the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. As displayed in Table 4, The Vp and Dp of the Cu-Agx/SiO2 (B) catalysts changed slightly after being doped with Ag promoter. With the increase of the Ag/Cu mass ratio, the SBET of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts showed a volcanic trend, and achieved the maximum value of 465.2 m2·g−1 in case of Ag/Cu mass ratio at 0.04. Nevertheless, further increasing Ag/Cu mass ratio brought about a gradual decline in SBET, which could be attributed to the excessive addition of Ag species covered the surface of the catalyst. In addition, it was apparent that the DCu and SCu of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited the similar change pattern as the SBET, and the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst afforded the maximum values of 24.9 and 27.8 m2·g−1. It is known that DCu and SCu are two key factors that determine the catalytic activity of Cu-based catalysts in DMO hydrogenation [28]. Therefore, we could speculate that the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst with Ag/Cu mass ratio of 0.04 afforded the optimal catalytic activity, which was consistent with the previous activity evaluation results. 3.3 Catalyst crystalline phase and morphology To explore the effect of silver promoter on the phase structure of Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts were characterized by XRD patterns. Notably, a broad amorphous SiO2 diffraction peak emerged at 2θ = 22.8º, suggesting that doping with Ag promoter slimly changed the crystal structure of Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Three obvious characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO for the calcined Cu/SiO2 catalyst appeared at 2θ = 35.5º, 38.7º, 48.8º (JCPDS 45-0937). As shown in Fig. 4 a, after doping Ag species, the diffraction peak intensity of CuO showed different degrees of enhancement, following the order Cu-Ag0.2/SiO2 (A)>Cu-Ag0.15/SiO2 (A)>Cu-Ag0.1/SiO2 (A)>Cu-Ag0.02/SiO2 (A)>Cu-Ag0.06/SiO2 (A)>Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A)>Cu/SiO2 (Fig. 4a). The result showed that adding Ag species by using preparation method A aggravated the aggregation and growth of CuO particles. As presented in Fig. 5 a, with the increase of Ag loading, the intensity of the CuO diffraction peaks initially decreased and then increased, and reached the weakest intensity in case of A/Cu mass ratio at 0.04. The result indicates that adding a suitable amount of Ag content by using preparation method B could inhibit the aggregation and growth of CuO particles. Significantly, in the spectrums of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts, when the Ag/Cu mass ratio was no less than 1.0, the Ag2O diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ=38.2º and 44.3º, and their intensity gradually increased with the increase of Ag loading (Figs. 4a and 5a). This might be attributed to the fact that Cu species encapsulated Ag species when Ag content was low, while they separated from each other when Ag content was high. Upon reduction at 493 K, CuO diffraction peaks (35.5º, 38.7º and 48.8º) of all the reduced Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts disappeared. Instead, three strong and broad diffraction peaks emerged at 2θ of 43.3º, 50.4º and 74.1º, which were ascribable to the Cu0 (111), (200), and (220) planes (JCPDS 04-0836), respectively (Figs. 4b and 5b). It is worth noting that upon closer inspection of these peaks, the Cu0 peak shifts towards lower 2θ values after the addition of Ag species to the Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 5b). The result indicated that CuAg alloy was formed in the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts. Moreover, a peak center at 2θ = 36.5º was assigned to the (111) lattice face of Cu2O species (JCPDS05-0667), which originated from the strong interaction between the active component Cu and support SiO2, making divalent copper ion partially reduced to univalent copper ion [30] (Figs. 4b and 5b). Moreover, increasing the content of the Ag promoter leaded to diminishing the intensity of the Cu2O diffraction peak. For the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts, after adding Ag species, the intensity of Cu0 diffraction peaks exhibited the similar trend as that of CuO diffraction peaks intensity. The result suggested that adding Ag species by using preparation method A could increase the crystallite size of Cu0 and decrease the dispersion of Cu0 species. For the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts, after adding Ag species, the intensity of Cu0 diffraction peaks also exhibited the similar trend as that of CuO diffraction peaks intensity, and the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts possessed the weakest intensity. The result suggested that adding Ag species by using preparation method B could decrease the crystallite size of Cu0 and increase the dispersion of Cu0 species. Therefore, we could speculate the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts had better catalytic performance, which was consistent with the previous catalytic evaluation results. As shown in Figs. 4b and 5b, a diffraction peak appeared at 2θ = 38.2º could be attributed to the Ag2O diffraction peak, because Ag2O could only be reduced to Ag0 at a reduction temperature higher than 623 K [31]. In addition, when the Ag/Cu mass ratio was greater than 0.06, other diffraction peaks of Ag2O gradually appeared at 2θ = 44.3º, 64.5º, and 77.6º, and their intensity became stronger with the increase of Ag content. TEM was used to observe the surface morphology of the reduced Cu/SiO2, Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the black metallic Cu particles were relatively evenly embedded on the surface of the light gray SiO2 support, accompanied by a certain degree of agglomeration. Based on the statistical results of TEM images, the average particles size was approximate 8.4 nm. However, after adding Ag species to the calcined Ag/SiO2 precursor, the metallic Cu particles of the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst aggregated and grew into larger spherical particles with an average particle diameter of approximate 11.3 nm (Fig. 6b). Conversely, the metallic Cu particles of the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst became smaller and more uniformly dispersed, and the average particle diameter was about 4.5 nm (Fig. 6c). These results were consistent with the above XRD results. Subsequently, High-resolution TEM energy-dispersive spectroscopy (HRTEM-EDS) characterization was carried out on the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts (Figs. 7 and S6). As shown in Fig. 7, the lattice fringes interval of a representative metal particles in Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) was 0.192 nm, locating between Ag (111) (0.236 nm), Ag (200) (0.204 nm) and Cu(200) (0.181 nm), which suggested the CuAg alloy was formed in Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst after reduction. Moreover, the EDS data showed that the Cu and Ag species were coexistent on the surface of the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts (Figs. 7 and S6). 3.4 Reducibility and surface acid properties To explore and compare the influence of different preparation methods and silver species content on the reduction capacity of the catalysts, the calcined Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts were tested by H2-TPR (Fig. 8 ). The unmodified Cu/SiO2 catalyst presented unique reduction peak at about 505K, associating with the reduction of highly dispersed Cu species [32]. Notably, the H2 reduction peaks of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts gradually moved towards the low temperature direction with the increase of Ag species content, which indicated that there was an intense mutual effect between active component Cu and Ag promoter. The result was consistent with the result reported by Zhou et al [33]. Furthermore, the reduction peaks of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts were more inclined to the direction of low temperature by comparing the different effects of the Ag promoter on the two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts developed by different preparation methods. This might be caused by the intense mutual effect between active component Cu and Ag promoter on the surface of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts than that of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts. 3.5 Chemical states of surface species From the above evaluation results, the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited better catalytic performance. Thus, we deeply investigated the chemical composition and chemical states of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts by XPS and XAES spectra (Fig. 9 ). According to previous reports, the binding energy of Cu2p 3/2 of CuO was approximate 933.5 eV, while the binding energy centered at above 934.9 eV was attributed to the highly dispersed bivalent copper ion, which strongly interacted with SiO2 supports [18,30,32]. As exhibited in Fig. 9a, two main peaks emerged at binding energies of 932.5 eV and 952.4 eV, which were conventionally assigned to Cu2p 3/2 and Cu2p 1/2, indicating that the Cu2+ species had been reduced to Cu0 or Cu+ due to the disappearance of 2p→3d satellite peaks around 933.5 eV or 934.9 eV [34]. Considering that the binding energies of Cu0 and Cu+ were very close, we adopted Cu LMM XAES spectrum to separate them from each other. The asymmetric and broad Auger peak were deconvoluted into two overlapped peaks at 913.8-914.6 eV and 918.2-918.5 eV, assigned to Cu+ and Cu0 species, respectively (Fig. 9b) [32,35]. These results indicated that Cu+ and Cu0 coexist on the surface of the reduced Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts. From the deconvolution results, the content of Ag promoter had a strong correlation with the distribution of Cu+ and Cu0 on the catalysts surface. The Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) (Noted as XCu+) intensity ratio spiked rapidly and then fell away, reaching the acme (52.6%) of the curve with the Ag/Cu mass ratio of 0.04 (Table 5 ). These results corresponded with the above activity evaluation and XRD results of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts, and further attested that Cu species strongly interacted with Ag species. According to the previous literature, two distinct peaks emerging at about 368.1 eV and 374.1 eV could be classified as Ag 3d 5/2 and Ag 3d 3/2, respectively. Notably, with the increase of Ag species content, the intensity of the two peaks became stronger and broader. These results suggested that there was a strong interaction between the Ag species and substrate [36]. 3.6 Comparison of catalytic performance of two types of Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts Generally, the Cu-based or Ag-based catalysts were mainly used for the DMO-to-MG reaction. However, these two types of catalysts have some shortcomings in practical applications. Although the Cu-based catalysts could obtained at low cost, the yield of MG was too low on account of the low Con.DMO at low-temperature or low Sel.MG at high-temperature [10,37]. Compared with Cu-based catalysts, Ag-based catalysts presented better Sel.MG due to their weaker hydrogenolysis effect in the DMO-to-MG reaction [10,37]. However, the relatively high cost of the Ag-based catalysts with high Ag loading limited the large-scale application of catalysts. Combining the respective characteristics of these two catalysts, the effective Cu-Ag bimetallic catalysts with low Ag loading were synthesised by using mothod A to achieve the goal of low cost and high MG yield. The XRD spectra and TEM images of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts revealed that the addition of Ag promoter by using preparation method A leaded to the increase of Cu particles size and the decrease of the dispersion of Cu species, resulting in a drop in catalytic activity. However, the Sel.MG of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts was greatly improved, especially when the Ag/Cu mass ratio was 2, reaching a maximum of 95.1% (Con.DMO = 97.2%) at 473 K. And when the reaction temperature rose to 493K, the Sel.EG of the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (A) catalyst was 93.6%, while that of unmodified Cu/SiO2 catalyst was only 89.7%. These results indicated that most of the silver species covered the surface of the copper species, which was more conducive to the hydrogenation of DMO to form MG. And the interaction between copper and silver species could effectively reduce the selectivity of by-products and increase the selectivity of EG at high-temperature. Therefore, a reasonable schematic diagram was proposed based on the above results (Scheme 3 ). In contrast, the introduction of Ag promoter by using preparation method B could greatly improve the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, which was completely different from the catalytic performance of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts. The Con.DMO and Sel.EG of the optimal Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst were 100% and 97.4% at 463 K, while that of Cu/SiO2 catalyst were only 94.7% and 51.1% under identical conditions. The XRD spectrums and TEM images of the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts suggested that the addition of Ag promoter by using preparation method B could contribute to restraining the growth of Cu particles, promoting the dispersion of Cu species, generating more active sites and then improving catalytic activity. These results indicated that the strong interaction between the encapsulated Cu and Ag species could effectively enhance the low-temperature catalytic activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts, which were consistent with the previous reports [18,21,38]. According to the above results, we could conclude that the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited better low-temperature catalytic activity and EG selectivity, while the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts possessed poor catalytic activity but better MG selectivity. Therefore, we could adopt different preparation methods to synthesize the corresponding catalysts for regulating the selectivity of MG and EG according to actual needs. 3.7 Structure–performance relationship Generally, Cu0 and Cu+ sites activate the hydrogen molecules, ester and acyl groups respectively, especially their synergistic promotion is helpful for the DMO hydrogenation over Cu-based catalysts [14,39]. Based on the above characterization results, there was an intense mutual effect between Cu and Ag species, which induced the formation of CuAg alloy and affected the distribution of Cu+ and Cu0 on the surface. The XCu+ ratio was considered to be directly related to the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts [10,11,18,21,37]. It was generally believed that a low XCu+ ratio corresponded to a low catalytic activity, and a higher XCu+ ratio corresponded to a superior catalytic activity. The XCu+ ratio and TOF value enhanced with the increment of the Ag/Cu mass ratio, and reached the maximum value simultaneously when the Ag/Cu mass ratio was 0.04 (Fig. 10 ). The maximum values of XCu+ and TOF were 52.6% and 3.0 h−1. Nevertheless, further increasing the Ag loading could bring about a decrease in both the XCu+ ratio and TOF value. These results were consistent with the catalytic activity evaluation results of Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts (Fig. 1b). The reason behind this phenomenon was that the introduction of an appropriate amount of silver content could contribute to enhancing the electronic effect between the Cu and Ag species, promote the formation of CuAg alloys, improve the XCu+ ratio on the surface and thus obtain the superior catalytic activity. On the contrary, excessive Ag would enrich on the surface of the catalysts and cover the copper particles, which could hinder the contact or entry of the reactants, resulting in the reduction of the activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Therefore, an appropriate surface Cu+ and Cu0 concentration was an essential factor in determining the catalytic activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts. In addition, a reasonable schematic diagram was proposed based on the above results (Scheme 4 ). Although the monometallic Cu/SiO2 catalyst has relatively excellent catalytic activity, their poor stability is difficult to meet the demands of industrial production. According to previous reports, the incorporation of Ag species to the Cu/SiO2 catalysts could contribute to stabilizing the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Herein, a novel and efficient Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst was developed by sol-gel coupled with impregnation method. After long-term stability test, the catalytic activity of the monometallic Cu/SiO2 catalyst decreased sharply within 100 h, while Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst still maintained excellent catalytic activity within 150 h. The used Cu/SiO2 and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts were further characterized and analyzed by a variety of characterization techniques to explore the role of Ag promoter in stabilizing the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The size of copper particles for the pure Cu/SiO2 catalyst agglomerated and increased to 17.7 nm from initial 10.5 nm after 100 h long-term stability test (Fig. 11 ). In contrast, the copper particles size of Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst only grew from 5.6 nm to 7.8 nm after 150 h of continuous reaction under the identical condition. To observe the agglomeration of copper particles on the surface of the catalyst more intuitively after the reaction, the used Cu/SiO2 and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts were characterized by TEM (Fig. 12 ). The copper particles on the surface of the used Cu/SiO2 catalyst agglomerated seriously, and the cooper particles size became larger obviously after 100 h of continuous reaction. Nevertheless, no visible agglomeration occurred on the surface of used Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst with the copper particles size increasing slightly. The XRD and TEM results indicated that the agglomeration of copper particles was a crucial factor leading to the deactivation of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts in the DMO hydrogenation process. The introduction of moderate silver promoter by preparation method B could facilitate suppressing the aggregation of the copper species, promoting the DCu and stabilizing the catalytic activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The related structural and textural properties of the used Cu/SiO2 and Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalysts were also summarized in Table 6 . Notably, the content of copper species declined markedly from 14.34% to 13.12% after 100 h of continuous reaction. However, for the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst, the copper content and silver content were basically unchanged after 150 h of continuous reaction under the same conditions. These results suggested that the loss of active component Cu species during the reaction was a non-negligible factor for the decrease of Cu/SiO2 catalyst activity, and doping Ag promoter in the catalyst could form a CuAg alloy to stabilize the copper species. Besides, for the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the SBET, Vp and dp were all greatly reduced after 100 h of continuous reaction. Conversely, for the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst, these three data were not significantly reduced. The reason for the significant decrease in SBET, Vp and dp of Cu/SiO2 catalyst arose from the sintering and agglomeration of the surface active component Cu during the reaction. These results proved that the introduction of Ag promoter by using preparation method B could stabilize the structure of Cu/SiO2 catalyst, and reduce the sintering and agglomeration of the surface active component Cu species. Overall, the principal factors for the deactivation of Cu/SiO2 catalyst during DMO hydrogenation reaction might result from the growth of Cu particles size caused by the agglomeration of surface active Cu species, the decrease of dispersion of cooper species, the loss of cooper loading and the changes of catalyst structure. The introduction of small amount of Ag promoter by using preparation method B could effectively prevent the growth of Cu particles size, improve the dispersion of cooper species, prevent the loss of the cooper loading and stabilize the Cu/SiO2 catalyst structure, thereby maintaining superior catalytic activity and stability in the reaction of DMO hydrogenation to produce EG. 4 Conclusions This work presents two types of Ag promoted Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts developed by sol-gel coupled with two different impregnation methods exhibit distinct catalytic activity and tunable selectively in the hydrogenation of DMO. The distinction between Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) and Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts was derived from the order of doping the Ag promoter during the preparation process. Evaluation results suggested that the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited better low-temperature catalytic activity and EG selectivity, while the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts possessed better MG selectivity. Among them, the optimized Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst obtained the highest values of XCu+ and TOF, reaching a maximum Sel.EG of 97.4% (Con.DMO = 100%) at 463 K. Characterization results demonstrated that doping with Ag promoter to calcined Cu/SiO2 resulted in increasing the Cu particles size, decreasing of the dispersion of Cu species, and reducing the catalytic activity of Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Nevertheless, the introduction of Ag promoter to dried Cu/SiO2 contributed to suppressing the growth of Cu particles, promoting the dispersion of Cu species, generating more active sites, reinforcing the interaction between Cu and Ag species by the formation of CuAg alloy, adjusting the distribution of Cu species, and then improving the catalytic activity of Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Moreover, the monometallic Cu/SiO2 catalyst deactivated rapidly within 100 h, while Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst still maintained excellent catalytic performance within 150 h. XRD, TEM, BET and ICP-OES results proved that the main reasons for the deactivation of pure Cu/SiO2 catalyst could ascribe to the growth of copper particles size, the decrease of dispersion of cooper species, the loss of Cu content and the changes of catalyst structure. Doping with an appropriate amount of sliver promoter by using preparation method B could effectively maintain the stability of the catalyst and prolong the lifetime of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts to meet the requirements of industrial production. coredata.dc:description: We developed two types of silver promoted Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts by sol-gel coupled with two different impregnation methods, which exhibited distinct catalytic activity and tunable selectivity in the dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation. Impregnation method A was introduction of Ag promoter after calcination of Cu/SiO2 while impregnation method B was before its calcination. As a result, the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (A) catalysts possessed inferior catalytic activity but higher methyl glycolate (MG) selectivity, while the Cu-Ag x /SiO2 (B) catalysts exhibited superior low-temperature catalytic activity and higher ethylene glycol (EG) selectivity under the same conditions (P = 2.0 MPa, T = 463 K, H2/DMO molar ratio = 50). Experimental results revealed that doping with silver species into Cu/SiO2 catalysts by using impregnation method A would aggravate the agglomeration of Cu particles and decrease Cu dispersion, thereby reducing the catalytic activity. In contrast, the introduction of silver promoter by using impregnation method B was conducive to inhibiting the growth of Cu particles, promoting Cu dispersion, and enhancing the interaction between Cu and Ag species. Moreover, the distribution of Cu species was regulated and thus maintain suitable Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) ratio after Ag addition, thereby improving the catalytic activity over the Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst. In addition, the monometallic Cu/SiO2 catalyst deactivated rapidly within 100 h, while the average EG selectivity of the optimal Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst was no less than 97% even after 150 h stability test at a low temperature of 463 K. Systematic study found that the Ag promoter in Cu-Ag0.04/SiO2 (B) catalyst played an essential role in stabilizing the catalyst structure and reducing the sintering and agglomeration of copper particles, thus greatly improving the stability of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic Cu-Ag/SiO2 catalysts with tunable product selectivity and enhanced low-temperature stability in the dimethyl oxalate hydrogenation
